title: Measuring the Mental Cost of Social Media
text:
Mental health has become one of the most pressing public health challenges of our time. In this brief data and coding tutorial, we will walk through a simple data analysis project that explores the relationship between social media use and self-reported mental well-being.

Using data and Pandas functions found in Python packages, we will demonstrate how to clean, categorize, and visualize survey responses to see potential correlations between screen time and depression.
Disclaimer: This analysis will only show correlation, not causation.

title: Measuring the Mental Cost of Social Media
text:
Mental health has become one of the most pressing public health challenges of our time. In this brief data and coding tutorial, we will walk through a simple data analysis project that explores the relationship between social media use and self-reported mental well-being.

Using data and Pandas functions found in Python packages, we will demonstrate how to clean, categorize, and visualize survey responses to see potential correlations between screen time and depression.
Disclaimer: This analysis will only show correlation, not causation.

title: Measuring the Mental Cost of Social Media
text:
Data & Methods

Data Import
For this project, we will use a publicly available dataset from Kaggle‚Äôs Public Health domain. The two key variables we‚Äôll focus on within our dataset are:
- Social Media Use (hours per day)
- Depression (self-reported increase in depressive feelings)
We‚Äôll start by importing the dataset into a Pandas DataFrame so we can begin cleaning and analyzing it.
``` python
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('smmh.csv')

```


Step 1: Categorize Social Media Use
To make comparisons clearer, we‚Äôll categorize respondents into time-use categories based on their daily social media usage.
-   0 -> Less than an hour
-   1 -> 1-2 hrs/day
-   2 -> 2-3 hrs/day
-   3 -> 3-4 hrs/day
-   4 -> 4-5 hrs/day
-   5 -> 5+ hrs/day


Step 2: Compute Average Depression by Group.

Next, we‚Äôll calculate how depression scores differ across these categories. A heatmap provides a quick way to visualize the relationship between time spent on social media and self-reported depression.
import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import chi2_contingency
from scipy.stats import chi2
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

crosstabDT = pd.crosstab(index = df.AvgTime , columns = df.Depressed)
sns.heatmap(crosstabDT, annot = True, fmt='d')

plt.title('Mental Health and Media Use')

plt.show()



Plot

title: Measuring the Mental Cost of Social Media
text:
Results
Looking at the heatmap, you may notice a trend: the groups reporting the most daily social media use also tend to show higher depression scores. To better quantify this relationship, let‚Äôs calculate the average depression score for each category using python‚Äôs averages functions.
data = {
    "Depressed": [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
    "Less than an Hour": [14, 12, 4, 2, 2],
    "Between 1 and 2 hours": [13, 18, 20, 8, 11],
    "Between 2 and 3 hours": [13, 21, 21, 27, 19],
    "Between 3 and 4 hours": [10, 10, 30, 22, 21],
    "Between 4 and 5 hours": [5, 10, 15, 24, 13],
    "More than 5 hours": [5, 12, 27, 33, 39]
}

df = pd.DataFrame(data).set_index("Depressed")


averages = {}
for col in df.columns:
    total_counts = df[col].sum()
    weighted_sum = (df.index * df[col]).sum()  
    averages[col] = weighted_sum / total_counts


avg_scores = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(averages, orient="index", columns=["Average Depression Score"])
Here‚Äôs a summary table of the results:



Social Media Use
Avg. Depression Score




0 (<1 hr/day)
2.00


1 (1-2 hrs/day)
2.80


2 (2-3 hrs/day)
3.18


3 (3-4 hrs/day)
3.37


4 (4-5 hrs/day)
3.45


5 (5+ hrs/day)
3.77




Visualization
To make this trend easy to see, let‚Äôs plot these averages as a bar chart with matplotlib.pyplot and pandas packages!
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Data (from previous calculation)
averages = {
    "Less than an Hour": 2,
    "Between 1 and 2 hours": 2.8,
    "Between 2 and 3 hours": 3.18,
    "Between 3 and 4 hours": 3.37,
    "Between 4 and 5 hours": 3.45,
    "More than 5 hours": 3.77
}

# Convert to DataFrame
avg_scores = pd.DataFrame.from_dict(averages, orient="index", columns=["Average Depression Score"])

# Plot as bar chart
ax = avg_scores.plot(kind="bar", legend=False, figsize=(8,5), color="skyblue")

# Titles and labels
plt.title("Average Depression Score by Time Spent", fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel("Average Time Category")
plt.ylabel("Average Depression Score")
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha="right")  # tilt labels for readability
plt.ylim(0,5)  # since scores are on a 1‚Äì5 scale

# Show chart
plt.show()



Bar chart




Conclusion
From this simple analysis, a clear pattern emerges: higher reported depression is associated with heavier social media use.


Strengths: The dataset is relatively large, making trends easier to detect.

Limitations:


Correlation ‚â† causation.

Self-reported data introduces bias.

Important confounders (family, academics, socioeconomic status, etc.) are not included here.¬†




Call to Action
This tutorial demonstrates how a few lines of code can uncover meaningful patterns in public health data.

For students and peers: Try applying these steps to other health-related datasets and share your findings. You never know what you might discover!
Practical takeaway: Combining Python, Markdown, and visualization tools helps make data analysis clear, reproducible, and persuasive.



References & Links

Kaggle: Dataset reference

NIH Research Summary: Social media use linked to brain changes in teens

title: Measuring the Mental Cost of Social Media
text:
We will now take a look at the patterns and record our observations about the data.

Pattern observed: Higher reported depression is associated with heavier social media use.

Strengths: Large dataset.

Limitations:

Correlation ‚â† causation.

Self-reported data may introduce bias.

Potential confounders (family, academics, socioeconomic status) not modeled here.

title: Measuring the Mental Cost of Social Media
text:
For peers: Apply these steps to other health-related datasets and share reproducible analyses on GitHub Pages.

Practical skill: Data wrangling + Markdown summaries make public health data accessible and persuasive.
